posts.name: Ofek Harel
posts.cooked: I’m creating software that will run in the context of the driver-station computer, The program runs in the background, acts on enable, and stops on disable. Currently, it’s implemented by NT, meaning I listen to a custom key that the robot sends according to its state. The NI-DriverStation knows the robot’s current state, so can I access that info? is it exported in some way? filesystem / registry / events?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: We publish a copy of the robot state to NT. /FMSInfo/FMSControlData contains a copy of the DS control word to the Rio.  Bit 0 (mask 0x01) is 1 when enabled, 0 when disabled.

posts.name: Ofek Harel
posts.cooked: Oh nice, that’s convenient, Will I see this info on a non-fms environment?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Yes, it’s always active.  The only difference for FMS is that bit 4 (mask 0x10) will be 1 when FMS connected (so it’s important to mask and check, rather than just use direct values).

posts.name: Ofek Harel
posts.cooked: is there a specific way to detect the auto → disable → teleop? There is the trivial state-history logic though I’m searching for something more specific to this state, something that could only happen in a game or when in the practice mode in the ds-client

posts.name: Peter Johnson
system
posts.cooked: This topic was automatically closed 365 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.

data.fancy_title: Enable and Disable driver-station context knowledge
data.title: Enable and Disable driver-station context knowledge

accepted_answer.excerpt:
The full control word definition is here: 

You can use the autonomous bit in combination with enabled to detect when the robot is in teleop or autonomous modes (and the test bit will be 1 in test mode). 
I had some of the bits wrong in my posts above, edited to fix.
